docs.title: 1. P2 Edge Socket
docs.text:
Parallax Propeller 2 Socket (P2-EC) Warning

Not compatible with 32MB RAM upgrade (P2-EC32MB)

docs.title: 2. 5V DC Input
docs.text:
Maximum Voltage: 5.25v

Uses Phoenix Contact MSTBA style connector

docs.title: 3. Voltmeter for Battery #1
docs.text:
Do not apply more than 33v to the input, or you will damage the P2.

Uses Phoenix Contact MSTBA style connector

docs.title: 4. Voltmeter for Battery #2
docs.text:
Do not apply more than 33v to the input, or you will damage the P2.

Uses Phoenix Contact MSTBA style connector

docs.title: 5. Servo Power Input
docs.text:
Power input for the 32 servo ports

Warning

Do not exceed 6v on the servo input

Uses Phoenix Contact MSTBA style connector

docs.title: 6. Main fuse
docs.text: Fuse for 5v rail. Replace it with 3A ATM mini fuse

docs.title: 7. Servo fuse
docs.text:
Fuse for servo rail. Replace it with 15A ATM mini fuse

Current Warning

Exceeding these rating may cause overheating of the board traces and/or connectors

Servo channel current ratings:

10A Max total current

6.5A Max for each bank of 16

3A Max per channel

docs.title: 8. LED Power connector
docs.text:
Power input LED Output.

The voltage going in will be the WS281X(b) signal level

No current will be drawn from this input

Warning

This is not a fused input. Install a fuse on the input side for safe operation

docs.title: 9. P2 Accessory Ports
docs.text:
Parallax-compatible P2-EVAL accessory headers. Compatible with all accessories.

Accessory List:

Universal Motor Driver

HyperRAM & HyperFlash Add-on

HD Audio Add-on set

RTC Add-on

AV Add-on

Serial Host Add-on

Serial Device Add-on

Goertzel Add-on

Mini Proto Add-on

Control Add-on

microSD Add-on

P2 to MikroBUS Click

WX Adapter

docs.title: 10. I2C Ports
docs.text:
Four I2C Ports on a common bus

Refer to Pin Mappings for the internal connections

5v, 3.3v, SDA, SCL, GND starting from the PropPlug side

Warning

Do not mix-and-match any of the 3.3v rails. They have the same voltage, but connecting them may result in damage to your P2.

docs.title: 11. One-Wire Ports
docs.text:
4 One-Wire Ports on a common bus

Refer to Pin Mappings for the internal connections

5v, 3.3v, DATA, GND starting from the PropPlug side

Warning

Do not mix-and-match any of the 3.3v rails. They have the same voltage, but connecting them may result in damage to your P2.

docs.title: 12. LED Output Port
docs.text:
LED Port intended for a single data wire addressable LED segment (such as WS2812b, WS2811, etc...)

Logic level is shifted to the input voltage

docs.title: 13. RSL Output Port
docs.text:
The RSL port is intended for a robot status light. For example, a light that turns on when motors are enabled

Output Voltage: 5v Max Output Current: 1.3A

docs.title: 14. UART Communication Port
docs.text:
This port is intended to be used as a serial communication link between the P2 Board and a main processor like a Raspberry Pi, or another Kevinbot Core. While using this port is entirely optional, it may be required for more complex applications.

Tip

Using shielded cable is recommended at higher data rates

docs.title: 15. External Reset Button Port
docs.text: This port is for an external PC-like reset button. A connection between the two pins will result in the CPU restarting.

docs.title: 16. External Error Buzzer Port
docs.text:
This port is for a software-controlled external Piezo Buzzer.

Output Voltage: 5v Max Output Current: 1.3A

docs.title: 17. Reset Button
docs.text: Pressing the button will result in the CPU and code execution restarting.

docs.title: 18. LED Indicators
docs.text:
Indicates power rail statuses and UART port activity.

Light meanings: 

TX = UART transmitting
RX = UART receiving

SVO = Servo power rail
3V3 = P2 V24 rail
5V  = 5V Input rail

docs.title: 19. PropPlug programming interface
docs.text: Header for programming the P2. Designed for use with a Parallax Prop Plug

docs.title: 20. Internal DS18B20 thermometer
docs.text:
Important! Read this!

Every Kevinbot Core will have a different serial number identifier for the thermometer. It is required to know the serial number if you have any devices connected to the One-Wire ports

docs.title: 21. Second Servo Bank
docs.text:
This is the second bank of servo ports (S16 ~ S31) They are connected to a PCA9685 at I2C address 0x41

Each port has a maximum rating of 3A The whole bank has a rating of 6.5A

docs.title: 22. First Servo Bank
docs.text:
This is the first bank of servo ports (S0 ~ S15) They are connected to a PCA9685 at I2C address 0x40

Each port has a maximum rating of 3A The whole bank has a rating of 6.5A

docs.title: 23. Ground test points
docs.text: These ground points can be invaluable when debugging hardware. Clip your oscilloscope ground to them and debug away!

docs.title: 24. Battery Input Polyfuses
docs.text: These fuses are for the battery voltmeters. They auto-reset after tripped. They should never trip unless the board or P2 is damaged in some way.

docs.title: 25. Error Buzzer
docs.text: This is a piezo buzzer intended for error tones. In the standard Kevinbot code, it will play a startup chime, and continuously beep is an error has occurred.

docs.title: 26. Error Buzzer Enabler
docs.text: This jumper should be installed to enable the internal error buzzer. If the jumper is not installed, the external buzzer port will still be active.

docs.title: 27. Expansion connector
docs.text: This connector is reserved for future use. A pinout is provided here

docs.title: Our Pledge
docs.text:
We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.

We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.

docs.title: Our Standards
docs.text:
Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for our community include:

  • Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
  • Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
  • Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
  • Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes, and learning from the experience
  • Focusing on what is best not just for us as individuals, but for the overall community

Examples of unacceptable behavior include:

  • The use of sexualized language or imagery, and sexual attention or advances of any kind
  • Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
  • Public or private harassment
  • Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or email address, without their explicit permission
  • Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting

docs.title: Enforcement Responsibilities
docs.text:
Community leaders are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards of acceptable behavior and will take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.

Community leaders have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, and will communicate reasons for moderation decisions when appropriate.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces. Examples of representing our community include using an official e-mail address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event.

docs.title: Enforcement
docs.text:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported to the community leaders responsible for enforcement at meowmeowahr@gmail.com. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated promptly and fairly.

All community leaders are obligated to respect the privacy and security of the reporter of any incident.

docs.title: Enforcement Guidelines
docs.text: Community leaders will follow these Community Impact Guidelines in determining the consequences for any action they deem in violation of this Code of Conduct:

docs.title: 1. Correction
docs.text:
Community Impact: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed unprofessional or unwelcome in the community.

Consequence: A private, written warning from community leaders, providing clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the behavior was inappropriate. A public apology may be requested.

docs.title: 2. Warning
docs.text:
Community Impact: A violation through a single incident or series of actions.

Consequence: A warning with consequences for continued behavior. No interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, for a specified period of time. This includes avoiding interactions in community spaces as well as external channels like social media. Violating these terms may lead to a temporary or permanent ban.

docs.title: 3. Temporary Ban
docs.text:
Community Impact: A serious violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior.

Consequence: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public communication with the community for a specified period of time. No public or private interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, is allowed during this period. Violating these terms may lead to a permanent ban.

docs.title: 4. Permanent Ban
docs.text:
Community Impact: Demonstrating a pattern of violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment of an individual, or aggression toward or disparagement of classes of individuals.

Consequence: A permanent ban from any sort of public interaction within the community.

docs.title: Attribution
docs.text:
This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html.

Community Impact Guidelines were inspired by Mozilla's code of conduct enforcement ladder.

For answers to common questions about this code of conduct, see the FAQ at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations are available at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to Kevinbot Core! ❤️ Your contributions, whether in code, documentation, or ideas, help the project grow. Please take a moment to review this guide to make the process easier for everyone.

docs.title: Ways to Support the Project
docs.text: Even if you don’t have time to contribute directly, you can support us by: - Starring the repository - Sharing it on social media - Mentioning it in your project’s README

docs.title: I Have a Question
docs.text:
Before asking: 1. Check the Documentation. 2. Search the Issues and Discussions.

Still need help? Open a new topic in Q&A, providing as much context as possible.

docs.title: Before Submitting a Bug Report
docs.text:
1. Make sure you're using the latest KiCAD version (if applicable).
  2. Verify the issue isn't due to configuration or environment issues.
  3. Search the bug tracker to see if the issue has already been reported.
  4. Gather the following details:
    • Software versions (e.g., KiCAD, P2 Compiler)
    • Reproduction steps or related input/output

docs.title: Submitting a Bug Report
docs.text:
Sensitive issues (e.g., security bugs) should be reported via email at meowmeowahr@gmail.com.

For all other issues: - Open a GitHub issue. - Describe the expected and actual behavior, along with clear reproduction steps. - Include the details you gathered earlier.

docs.title: Before Submitting an Enhancement
docs.text:
1. Make sure you're using the latest version.
  2. Check the documentation to ensure the feature isn’t already covered.
  3. Search the issue tracker for similar suggestions.

docs.title: Submitting an Enhancement Suggestion
docs.text:
1. Discuss your idea in the Discussions section.
  2. Once your idea is clear, open a new issue with:
    • A descriptive title
    • A detailed explanation of the suggestion and expected outcome
    • Why the feature would benefit users

docs.title: Learn about Kevinbot Core
docs.text: The Kevinbot Core is a Parallax Propeller 2 Edge Breakout Board catered for robotics use. Originally designed only for use in Kevinbot v3, the board can be used for any P2-based robotics project.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Compatible with standard P2 Edge (will not work with the 32 MB option)
  • Prop-Plug Programming Interface
  • 32 Servo Outputs
  • Four One-Wire Ports
  • Four I2C Ports
  • One Serial UART Port
  • One RSL (Status Light) Port
  • Two Voltmeters (1v ~ 33v)
  • One Level-Shifted WS281X(b) port
  • Four 2x6 Way P2 accessory headers
  • Internal and External Error Buzzer
  • Reset Button and External Reset button port
  • Internal DS18b20 thermometer
  • Fully Open Source Design

docs.title: General P2 Objects
docs.text:
jm_ds18b20.spin2 A driver can be found here

This will work for interfacing with the single sensor on the board, or external sensors via the One-Wire ports. You can use the One-Wire scanner tool on the Kevinbot v3 GitHub Repo

ka_pca9685.spin2 The driver can be found here

This is the driver for controlling the servo banks. You will need to initialize two instances of the driver to use both banks.
